thread.title: Steve Smith hundred video 2015: Australia, NSW captain’s brilliant year just got better |
thread.title_full: Steve Smith hundred video 2015: Australia, NSW captain’s brilliant year just got better | The Courier-Mail

author: couriermail.com.au
title: Steve Smith hundred video 2015: Australia, NSW captain’s brilliant year just got better |
text:
Batting for New South Wales against Queensland in the Matador Cup on Friday, Smith belted 136 not out off 142 balls.
Incredibly that was his ninth century across all formats in 2015, taking in a massive year of cricket that’s included a World Cup, an Ashes tour and matches against India and West Indies.
LIVE: NEW SOUTH WALES V QUEENSLAND
As was shown by his remarkable performances when filling in for Michael Clarke last summer, the added responsibility of captaincy only seems to make Smith a better batsman.
The 26-year-old has been captain in all 11 of the matches he’s played since the end of the Ashes series, taking in one-day and T20 internationals against England, and the current Matador Cup tournament.
From those 11 matches, he’s scored 597 runs at an average of 66.33.
Here is a list of all the centuries hit by Steve Smith this calendar year.
T ESTS
117 v India at Sydney Cricket Ground, January 6
Topping off a record-breaking series, Smith led Australia to victory in the New Year’s Test with another breathtaking century against a tired Indian bowling attack. In the process, he became the first Australian to score a hundred in every match of a four-Test series, and the first to score a hundred in his first three Tests as captain.
Smith on his way to 199 against West Indies in Jamaica. Source: Getty Images
199 v West Indies at Sabina Park, June 11
Michael Clarke was back at the helm but there was no stopping Smith, who blasted his way to within one run of a maiden double century before being trapped lbw by paceman Jerome Taylor.
215 v England at Lord’s, July 16
Smith didn’t have to wait to long to reach the coveted double ton, bringing it up at the home of cricket in an emphatic riposte to those in the UK who didn’t believe his technique was good enough to bat at No.3. Australia went on to romp to victory by a whopping 405 runs.
143 v England at The Oval, August 20
The series was over but, after a brief hiatus, Smith’s rediscovered his thirst for runs with a majestic 143 off 252 balls at The Oval, showing good patience early on before exploding late in an innings that featured 17 fours and two sixes.
Smith salutes the crowd after reaching his century against England at The Oval. Source: Getty Images
ONE-DAY INTERNATIONALS
102 not out v England at Blundstone Arena, January 23
In his first match as Australia’s one-day captain, Smith enhanced his reputation as a ‘closer’ by engineering a successful 300-plus run chase in an innings where no other Australian batsman reached 50. His unbeaten 95-ball innings included six boundaries and a monstrous straight six late in the match.
Steve Smith celebrates his century during the World Cup semi-final against India. Picture: Brett Costello. Source: News Corp Australia
105 v India in an ODI at The Sydney Cricket Ground, March 26
The pressure was well and truly on when Smith walked to the middle of the SCG with the score 1-15 in the fourth over of a World Cup semi-final against India. Thirty overs later the score was 2-197, with Smith having blasted 105 off just 93 balls to set up an emphatic victory against the reigning world champions.
ONE-DAY DOMESTIC CRICKET
143 not out v CA XI at Bankstown Oval, October 5
The opposition may not have quite been of the calibre he had become accustomed to, but there are very few ‘off’ days for Smith and this was no exception as he blasted a hapless Cricket Australia XI attack at Bankstown Oval on the opening day of the Matador Cup. His knock included 10 fours and five sixes.
Smith’s incredible run of form has continued in the Matador Cup. Picture: Mark Evans. Source: News Corp Australia
136 not out v Queensland at Drummoyne Oval, October 16
After enduring a rare lean trot in which he scored consecutive ducks, Smith bounced back with a brilliant ton against Queensland on Friday. At first he had to lead a recovery job, coming to the crease in the first over and still having to bide his time with NSW 3-83 early in its innings. Naturally Smith stuck around and was able to unleash his impressive array of strokes late in the innings, particularly towards the leg side.
FIRST-CLASS CRICKET
111 retired v Kent in Canterbury, June 2
Australia’s vice-captain at the time warmed up for this year’s Ashes series with a casual hundred against Kent, showing his ability to adjust to the different conditions encountered in England.
Originally published as Smith’s incredible 2015 just got better
